author: Staff Reporter
text:
Justice S Tamilvanan of the Madras High Court, who demitted office on Friday, sought appointment of persons from oppressed communities to the judiciary.

“It cannot be disputed that there should be no caste-based elevation of judges. However, to maintain social justice, it is essential to provide adequate representation to the downtrodden, other Backward Classes and women in the case of elevation of judges,” he said in his farewell address.

Requesting the Chief Justice and the collegium of judges to consider social justice in judges’ appointments, Justice Mr. Tamilvanan said, “Though I have never been in a political, communal or caste-based organisation, I am interested in social justice.”

“Unless, we create a conducive atmosphere, by providing reasonable opportunity to all sections of people, we cannot imagine anything on the implementation of fundamental rights, especially equality before law as enshrined in the Constitution,” the judge said.

Justice Mr. Tamilvanan was elevated as a judge of Madras High Court in 2005.

Retiring judge makes an appeal to Chief Justice, collegium
title: Call for social justice in appointment of judges
